p.s: The given text is an excerpt from chapter 6 at the end of part two from the book The Tortilla Curtain which was written by T. C. Boyle in 1995 and deals with the contrast of the living conditions and moral views of illegal mexicanMexican immigrants, opposed to a covert racist American, living in California.

This is shown by the 41 year old41-year-old American, Delaney Mossbacher, who lives in a spanishSpanish mission style house in Arroyo Blanco and takes pride in being a liberal humanist with an expensive car.
He lives with his second wife Kyra, who is a real estate agent and her six year oldsix-year-old jordanJordan.
Delaney works as a writer for a nature magazine where he calls himself a pilgrim.

He keeps his car in perfect condition, which makes it an even bigger hsock for him, when he hits the 33 year old33-year-old Cándido Rincon with it, who lives with his 17 year old17-year-old pregnant girlfriend, América, in a canyon near Arroyo Blanco.
José Navidad, who is also a mexicanMexican illegal immigrant, lives in similairsimilar conditions.
He also has a camp in the canyon, where Delaney loves to go on hikes.
Since Delaney values nature highly, he is shocked to see trash and garbage at José Navidad's camp, whom he runs into while hiking.
Kyra also runs into José Navidad at a house she is selling, and feels lucky to be left unscathed, since she feels threatened by him.
Due to the many illegal immigrants living in California DelaneysDelaney's neighbours want to erect a wall around their community to keep criminals out.
Apart from Delaney only Todd Sweets is also against the idea of a wall being built.
In the given scene Delaney tries to get rid of Todd Sweets, who wants them to meet and discuss a plan, through which they can convince others against the wall.
Delaney tells him that he will hear from him and walks away while lost in thought.
When he reaches a neighboursneighbour's house he sees a man walking across the lawn and immidiatelyimmediately assumes that he is a criminal, since he is Mexican.
When he asks the Mexican, why he is here the man does not answer him.
At this moment Delaney recognizes him as José Navidad, though he does not know his name.
Delaney realizes that this is the man who threatened his wife and repeats his question angrily.
José answers mockingly, which goads Delaney, into saying a racist phrase and grabbing the mansman's arm in a brutal motion.
The latter rips himself free and shouts at Delaney that he is only giving our flyers.
When Delaney does not believe him and threatens to call the police, José shows Delaney one of the flyers.
This leaves the latter shocked as well as dumbfounddumbfounded and gives José the chance to walk up to DelaneysDelaney's own house and deliver one of the papers there.
The scene ends with Delaney reading the flyer and seeing that it is an invitation to a community meeting, where the safety of the neighbourhood will be discussed.
This excerpt is relevant to the whole book since this is where Delaney first loosesloses his self control and gives into his racist feelings.
